repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body: This one, for example, breaks symmetry.
Symmetry with what? Looks like I forgot to change line 530. Would that make it symmetrical again?
Would it make sense to add a `CLAMP(foo, a, b)` macro for this? (Right now it's probably not used often enough to be worth it, but I personally find that easier to grok.)
Yeah I considered that. I went with just using MIN/MAX as they are semi-std functions, but looks like we may need `min()` and `max()` anyway.
Oh, I thought about it again. It's OK.

Hmm thinking about this, I think this might add a bit of ambiguity to the code as it could be interpreted as eith `CLAMP(min, foo, max)` or `CLAMP(foo, min, max)` (and any other permutation).

Maybe these cases could be written as either: `MAX(min, MIN(foo, max))` or `MIN(MAX(foo, min), max)`? So `min` always precedes `max`.

ah, true, that would be an issue with macros -- but a function could be documented? (`clamp(foo, min, max)` is the standard signature)

And removing the variations is exactly one of the motivations for introducing this (the other would be removing duplicate calls).

I've seen `minimum` and `maximum` as alternative names to avoid collision with `min`/`max`. (I think `min_i` is a bit too opaque.)

Out of interest: Some compilers are case-sensitive, so _could_ we just name them `MIN` and `MAX` (even though they're not "really" macros)?
We already have `MIN` and `MAX` and need to maintain them for non-`int` types.
Then `min_int` etc. would be nicer than `min_i`, IMO.

comment_regular_data.body:
> Some lead to two calls to a function instead of one.

Maybe we can introduce `int min(int, int)`, `int max(int, int)` implemented as functions for these cases?

> Some others break the symmetry between two adjacent if statements and make code harder to understand.

Which? I only changed the ones I thought made the code easier to read.

title: refactor: collapse statements in single assignments
